title: Akkadian language
summary: Akkadian (/É™ËˆkeÉªdiÉ™n/ akkadÃ», ğ’€ğ’…—ğ’ºğ’Œ‘ ak-ka-du-u2; logogram: ğ’Œµğ’†  URIKI)[1][2] is an extinct East Semitic language that was spoken in ancient Mesopotamia (Akkad, Assyria, Isin, Larsa and Babylonia) from the third millennium BC until its gradual replacement by Akkadian-influenced Old Aramaic among Mesopotamians by the 8th century BC.
